snippet: Guangzhou wants to improve quality of life through license plate auctions and lotteries expected to halve the number of new cars on the streets.
abstract: Guangzhou, China, has introduced license plate auctions and lotteries that will roughly halve the number of new cars on the streets; crackdown is the most restrictive in a series of moves by big Chinese cities that are putting quality-of-life issues ahead of short-term economic growth; moves, as startling to some as if Detroit restricted car ownership, come at a time when policy makers around the world are concerned about a sharp economic slowdown in China.
lead_paragraph: Guangzhou wants to improve quality of life through license plate auctions and lotteries expected to halve the number of new cars on the streets.

headline.seo: Guangzhou Moves to Limit New Cars
headline.main: A Chinese City Moves to Limit New Cars
